title: Man’s Best Friend (Until It’s Time to Show a House)
text:
Jim DiMartino

Broker associate at Strickland Group/Douglas Elliman

St. Petersburg, Fla.

I had a client who had seven yorkies—teeny-tiny dogs. The male dogs needed to wear a little diaper thing to prevent them from peeing in the house and marking their territories. The first time I met them, I made the mistake of saying, ‘Oh look, they are wearing diapers!’ The owners were so offended—‘They are not diapers, they are pee-pads.’

There wasn’t a lot of carpet in that house.

For every showing, they’d have to roust up seven dogs, put on the pee-pads. Sometimes they’d be late getting out of the house, and my clients would be standing there seeing the sellers shuffle the dogs out two by two into the van in 95-degree weather.

Tami Halton Pardee

founder/CEO of Halton Pardee + Partners

Los Angeles, Calif.



The house was in Culver City—a nice modern house priced a little under $2 million. I went over, nicely dressed—you dress up when you are going over to meet a client—and they had this pet pig. It was huge; it must have been 200 pounds. And it had wiry hair. It was one of those potbellied pigs, it must have been small when they bought it. My grandparents were farmers; they had pigs. I actually really like pigs—on a farm. Not pigs in a house.

Illustration: Boyoun Kim

It was bizarre. I was sitting there and the pig was right next to me. You have to act like everything is normal, but it was just weird. Everything had a pig stench to it, like a barn. Everything was dirty, like if you were going to a farm and saw floors covered with dirt and hay. The pig had full access to the house—well, the first floor. I don’t think it could get up the stairs.

I said, “We have to clean this up. Could the pig go stay with a relative?”

They said, “No, we want the pig to stay here.” They even wanted to put the pig in pictures of the house; they said it would make it unique.

I said, “We’re not selling the pig, we’re selling the house.” They seemed not to get it.

I went home and showered after that. I don’t think they ever sold their house. I think they took it off the market. They just really loved their pig.

Lauren Krawczyk

Realtor associate at Douglas Elliman

St. Petersburg, Fla.



It was a very large waterfront property, a nice expensive home, and the dog was there for the showing. We always tell people to take their dogs with them, but it can’t always be helped. The owner had dog-sitter issues. To alleviate stress, I said I’d take care of it.

It was a goldendoodle. He was a really sweet, excitable, overly friendly dog.

So I had the dog on a leash with me, actually walking him through the house during the showing. You don’t know—sometimes the buyers walk in and they could be afraid of dogs. And God forbid the dog has dirt on his paws and jumps on someone.

It got kind of distracting, so I thought, “Maybe I’ll put the dog in the backyard for a bit.” It was nice outside. I didn’t realize the gate was open.

We [the clients and I] were wandering around the house for 30 minutes, and then the doorbell rings. One of the neighbors had found the dog running through the neighborhood on a main road. I was mortified. The dog got inside, very excited, and peed on the very nice Restoration Hardware couch. Fortunately, the people were leaving; it was the end of the showing. I just ran and got any cleaning supplies I could. I’ve never sweated so much in my life.

—Edited from interviews
description: Agents recall trying to sell homes where dogs and even a potbellied pig ruled the roost.
